communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Email Metadata
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The following metadata for emails sent by all accounts operated by the mayor's office between the dates of April 7, 2025 and April 18, 2025: Sender, Recipient (To, CC, BCC), Date and time sent, Subject. As this is a request for metadata, please do not include the email body in the returned records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Mayor's Office :: C223271-042225
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Welcome to the City of Seattle Public Records Request Center (PRRC). Your request was received on April 22, 2025 and is appended below. Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your email contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center emails to your Inbox. 
 
The reference number for this request is C223271-042225. You will see this number in the title of any communications about this request. 
 
You will hear from a Public Disclosure Officer within five business days regarding the status of your request. 
 
Please visit the City of Seattle Public Records Request Center where you can manage your profile and access your request. Your login ID is: 185423-84386438@requests.muckrock.com
 
If a Public Disclosure Officer submitted your public disclosure request into the PRRC on your behalf, please login and complete your new user account by following these steps: 
 
  * Access the Public Records Request Center 
  * Select 'Forgot my Password' 
  * Enter your 'Login ID' (email address) 
  * A temporary password will be sent to you via email 
  * Login with the temporary password 
You may now visit the PRRC 'My Records Request Center' anytime!

communications.subject: City of Seattle Public Records Request Center - Invoice Ready :: C223271-042225
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Records in response to your public disclosure request C223271-042225 received on April 22, 2025 are now available. The cost for the records is as follows: 
 
Invoice Number: INV25-C223271-1 
Total: $1.25 
 
To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 Please note that you will need to disable any pop-up blockers to make a payment using the system. 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center.
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Find this request: C223271-042225. 
  * Select the 'View Invoices' button. 
 
  * Opens a pop-up window showing your invoice: INV25-C223271-1. 
  * Click on the invoice and then the 'Pay Now' button. 
  * Continue processing your payment. 
  * Select 'Done'. 
  * Once the payment process is done, you are returned to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * After your payment is successful you will receive an email from our payments center. 
Once your payment has been approved, we will send you an email with instructions on how to download your records. Note that City staff must manually upload records. Records will be available one to two business days after payment. 
 
Please let your public disclosure officer (PDO) know if you are unable to pay online; your PDO will work with you on alternative ways to make your payment. 
 
You have 30 days from today's date to pay for your records. If the City does not receive your payment within this time period, your request will be considered abandoned, and you will need to submit a new request. 
 Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your E-mail contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center E-mails to your Inbox. (mailto:seattle@mycusthelp.net) 
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records: 

The following metadata for emails sent by all accounts operated by the mayor's office between the dates of April 7, 2025 and April 18, 2025: Sender, Recipient (To, CC, BCC), Date and time sent, Subject. The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Sincerely, 

Rose Terse 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Foffice-of-the-mayor-241%252Femail-metadata-185423%252F%253Femail%253DEXECPDR%252540seattle.gov&url_auth_token=AAAj9sYRrCpZzSYtO2LZl3Hncb4%3A1u7Ppr%3AU_txSRyDpq26r5jtAmMQVut0l-Vksrmo0xqn6F8ie7Y 
The records being made available to you at this time include the following: the metadata you requested. 
To download your records, please: 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Select this request: C223271-042225. 
  * Select the 'View Files' button. 
  * You can download records individually or all at the same time by clicking 'Download All'. 
  *  Please save your records as you may only download them from the system three times. If you do not download your records within 30 days of request closure, the link to your records will expire. 
If you believe you have received privileged or confidential records in error, please notify the City of Seattle immediately, through the Public Records Request Center or by email. Privileged or confidential records provided or received in error should not be reviewed, used, disseminated, distributed, or copied, and should be destroyed immediately. Thank you in advance for your cooperation. 
We have redacted records that are exempt from disclosure under the Public Records Act. Please see the attached exemption log. 
The Mayor's Office has now provided all responsive records. We consider your request closed and plan to take no further action to fulfill this request. If you have any follow-up questions or would like to initiate an administrative appeal under MDAR 17-0002 Section 6, please contact us within 10 business days after downloading your records, after which this request will no longer be monitored for communications. You may also seek judicial review of our response to your request for a period of one year, beginning as of the date of this message, consistent with RCW 42.56.550. 
Sincerely, 
Kyle Ponton-Welty 
Office of the Mayor 
City of Seattle

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Patron Incident Reports - April/May 2025
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

1. All Patron Incident Reports submitted for the Area Manager 5 North Region from April 15, 2025 through May 15, 2025 inclusive of those dates.

2. All Patron Incident Reports submitted systemwide where the fields "Police Called" or "Security Called" are True from April 15, 2025 through May 15, 2025 inclusive of those dates.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit Lucy Parsons Labs for the purpose of public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Alexandra Gelzin

title: DPS Internal Records on PTSA Incidents – Centennial (Oct 2024 & Mar 2025)

communications.subject: Colorado Open Records Act Request: DPS Internal Records on PTSA Incidents – Centennial (Oct 2024 & Mar 2025)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Colorado Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I request access to the following public records under the Colorado Open Records Act (CORA), § 24-72-201 et seq., C.R.S., covering the period from October 1, 2024, through the date this request is received. These records concern internal communications within Denver Public Schools (DPS) related to two key incidents at Centennial School for Expeditionary Learning involving the Centennial PTSA and myself (Patrick Quigley):

- An October 23, 2024 incident in which PTSA Committee Co-Chair Michelle Frankel yelled and used profanity toward me, a parent volunteer, on school grounds and in front of students.
- A set of claims made on March 6, 2025, by PTSA Treasurer Eric Lyche, alleging that I violated policy, removed a student from the PTSA Clubs Program, and caused emotional distress to a parent.

For the purposes of this request, “communications” includes, but is not limited to: emails, text messages, meeting notes or summaries, records of phone or in-person conversations, chat messages (including Slack or Microsoft Teams), calendar invites, agendas, and any written or recorded documentation—including internal drafts or materials created by DPS personnel for internal use.

Requested Records:

Please produce all communications and records exchanged between or among the following DPS individuals or departments:

- Scott Wolf, Director of Operational Services
- Emily Volkert, Principal at Centennial
- DPS Human Resources, including Alui Kouassi
- DPS Legal or Risk Management personnel
- DPS Communications personnel
- Regional or instructional superintendents
- Family and Community Engagement (FACE)
- Volunteer Services (or department responsible for volunteer management / support)

...that reference or relate to:

- The October 2024 or March 2025 incidents
- Any use or discussion of my name in connection with those incidents, my volunteer role, or related complaints
- Internal guidance, recommendations, or direction—including from Mr. Wolf to Principal Volkert—regarding how to manage, respond to, or characterize either incident or any related communications involving the PTSA or me
- Internal evaluations or concerns regarding my volunteer role, including reputational risk, conflict management, or parent complaints
- Discussions or evaluations of DPS Board Policy KFA and its applicability to either incident
- Any internal discussion or evaluation of assumed risk, liability, or legal exposure for volunteers participating in programs on DPS campuses, including whether volunteers are considered covered, protected, or personally liable under DPS policy or practice
- Oversight of or internal evaluations related to the PTSA Clubs Program, including PTSA conduct, safety practices, volunteer management, policy compliance, or DPS’s responsibility for incidents involving PTSA volunteers
- Responses to my complaints or requests for retraction, including any internal assessment of reputational risk or incident handling

Please exclude records entirely unrelated to the individuals, incidents, or volunteer role described above (e.g., general personnel matters or unrelated school operations).

If any portion of this request yields no responsive records, I request confirmation of that outcome. If any records are withheld or redacted, please cite the specific legal exemption under § 24-72-204(3)(a), C.R.S., and provide a general description of the withheld material.

If clarification or narrowing would expedite fulfillment, please notify me at your earliest convenience.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Patrick Quigley

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fdenver-public-schools-5864%252Fdps-internal-records-on-ptsa-incidents-centennial-oct-2024-mar-2025-186885%252F%253Femail%253Dcora%252540dpsk12.org&url_auth_token=AABOPm4MTqHlrCgJ-bwXFFls9Es%3A1uI1Bf%3A0lrZk2peXWorARE32e9arZ0PwDQwv0cjhH83i52mqIM 

The Colorado Open Records Act requires a response within three business days (excludes holidays, closures and weekends). The three‐day timeline begins on the first business day following the receipt of the request.  Multiple requests in one email will be treated as one request for reimbursement purposes.  The district may also treat multiple requests concerning the same subject matter as one request.  The process is as follows: 
 
  * The CORA Officer will review your request and work with staff to determine: 
 
  * If the district is the custodian of the requested documents; 
  * How much staff time will be required to retrieve the documents (please note the below reimbursement policy for requests requiring more than one hour of staff time); and 
  * If an extension is necessary 
 
  * If applicable, within three business days of the receipt of the request, the CORA lead with notify you of the cost of your request and any extension needed to respond to your request. 
  * The CORA Officer will provide a final response to your request in accordance with the applicable CORA timeline after payment is received (as applicable). Please note: The Colorado Open Records Act only makes available public records that already exist. It does not require the creation of new records to respond to a request. It also does not require the district to manipulate or analyze existing information in a new way to respond to a request. CORA Reimbursement Policy ‐ 
The Colorado Open Records Act allows for the following reimbursement for reasonable costs associated with completing a request: 
 
  * Copying Expenses: We charge $0.25 for each hard‐copy page after the first 25 pages. 
  * Staff Time: For requests that require more than one hour of staff time, we charge $41.37 for each additional hour of staff time expended. 
  * There will be a retrieval charge for documents stored at an offsite facility, dependent on the number of boxes to be retrieved. 
  * Electronically stored files which are larger than 14MB will be transferred to a CD for a charge of $10 per CD. 
You can read more about the District’s CORA Policy 
You can monitor the progress of your request here.  here.  You will receive an email when your request has been completed. 
To monitor the progress or update this request please log into the CORA Request Center

DENVER PUBLIC SCHOOLS

communications.subject: RE: Colorado Open Records Act Request #R000523-052225
communications.communication:
Ms. Wheeler,
Thank you for your message. I am providing the requested clarification below to support the processing of this request.

Please limit the search for email and Google Chat communications to messages sent or received by the following DPS employees:
- Scott Wolf (DPS Director of Operational Services)
- Emily Volkert (Centennial Principal)
- Alui Kouassi (DPS Senior Human Resource School Partner)

Timeframe: October 1, 2024 through May 22, 2025

Search Criteria: Please use the list of search terms provided in the attached PDF titled " Search Terms - DPS Internal Communications"

This request is intended to identify internal DPS communications either initiated by or involving Mr. Wolf, Ms. Volkert, or Mr. Kouassi that relate to:
- The October 2024 or March 2025 incidents involving the Centennial PTSA, myself, or volunteer programs
- Oversight, enforcement, or interpretation of policy related to PTSA programs, non-DPS programs operating on DPS campus, or volunteers
- Legal, HR, or administrative responses to complaints
- Any internal evaluation of district liability, risk exposure, or reputational concerns

While some messages may involve additional departments (e.g., HR, Legal, FACE, Risk Management, Volunteer Services), I am not requesting a system-wide search across those teams. Please begin with communications to or from the three individuals listed above.

To minimize cost and redundancy, please consolidate and deduplicate any records that appear across multiple search terms, custodians, or systems. If a record hits on multiple terms or exists in multiple mailboxes, I request only one copy. Please reflect this in any fee estimate.

Please confirm whether this scope is enough to proceed.
Thank you,
Patrick Quigley

communications.subject: CORA Records Request :: R000523-052225
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Good Afternoon - I wanted to let you know that the email portion of your request produced over 28,000 emails deduplicated with those terms in them. As previously stated, staff will have to review those emails to ensure compliance with state and federal law (i.e. FERPA). The minimum amount of time for staff to review would be 233 hours, which would be an exorbitant cost to yourself and an inefficient use of staff time taking over a month to complete. 

I have provided you with two screenshots from our department of technology which shows the breakdown of the prevalence of the terms/phrases in the 28,000 emails. Hopefully, this will be useful to you begin able to modify/narrow your request to those emails responsive. 

Sincerely, 

Stacy Wheeler 
CORA Officer

communications.subject: RE: Colorado Open Records Act Request #R000523-052225
communications.communication:
Ms. Wheeler,
Thanks again for your work on this request—I’ve had a chance to go through the search summary you shared, which has been very helpful in understanding what was included and where we might be able to narrow things down.

One clarification: when I initially submitted the search terms, I used the paired-term format you recommended (e.g., “student” + “safety”) to help focus the results. However, based on the breakdown, it appears those paired terms were searched separately rather than together. For example, “student” and “safety” appear to have been run individually, which resulted in over 13,000 records—definitely not the intended outcome.

To help reduce volume and return more relevant results, I’d appreciate it if the attached paired terms could be searched using “AND” logic—where both terms appear within the same document. 

I’ve also reviewed the rest of the terms and removed some of the broader ones from consideration to help keep the search more targeted. Attached is a breakdown of:

- The combined search terms I’d like searched using “AND” logic
- The individual terms already searched that I’d still like included in the next round
- The individual terms already searched that I’d like removed from the next record count and estimate

Once the updated search is complete, please let me know the revised count of unique responsive records and any associated cost estimate. I’m happy to continue refining the scope if needed.

Please don’t hesitate to reach out if anything in the attachment needs clarification or if there’s a preferred format that would make things easier on your end.

Thanks again for your help in moving this forward.
Sincerely,
Patrick Quigley

communications.subject: CORA Records Request :: R000523-052225
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Good Afternoon - I am confirming with our Department of Technology that they did use the + logic in the search, normally they are very good at seeing that in the request and applying. It may be that the system cannot show the logic in the prevalence report. Again I am confirming with staff. 

I have sent your updated search terms for the team to conduct the search. 

Sincerely, 

Stacy Wheeler 
CORA Officer

communications.subject: CORA Records Request :: R000523-052225
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Good Afternoon - I did confirm with the Department of Technology (DoTs) the they in fact did run the initial search with the logic you provided and that the way they can run the "prevalence" report only can show each single word and not the logic used. 

They ran the email search with the new search terms you provided using only those with the logic + and there are still 11,700 emails that have those search terms. DoTs can narrow this pull, or example narrow to emails were at least 2 of the individuals in the search are on the email or narrowing the time frames or a third term such as your last name, etc. A review of all these emails will take staff nearly 100 hours. 

Note, even if a search term/phrase is in the original email the whole email thread will be pulled. 
Please let me know how you would like to proceed. 

Sincerely, 

Stacy Wheeler 
CORA Officer

communications.subject: RE: Colorado Open Records Act Request #R000523-052225
communications.communication:
Ms. Wheeler,
Thank you for providing the responsive records and privilege log for CORA request #R000523-052225. 

I’ve reviewed the documents, privilege log, and sworn statement regarding withheld materials. After reviewing the relevant CORA statutes and consulting with the Colorado Freedom of Information Coalition (CFOIC), I’d like to respectfully request the following:

1. Supplement to the Privilege Log
Under CORA § 24-72-204(3)(a)(XIII), the sworn statement accompanying any withheld records must:
“specifically describe each document withheld, explain why each such document is privileged, and why disclosure would cause substantial injury to the public interest.”

This standard was further clarified in Complete Colorado v. HCPF (Denver District Court, 2023), where the court found that general references to the “deliberative process” were not enough. The agency was ordered to provide a document-by-document justification, including a clear explanation of the anticipated harm to the public interest from disclosure.

At this time, the privilege log does not include this level of detail. It generally states that disclosure of all withheld records would “stifle honest and frank discussion,” but does not explain how this applies to each specific document or why that harm outweighs public access in each instance. I respectfully request a supplement to the privilege log providing the specific justification required for each withheld document.

2. Redacted Versions of Withheld Records
Where applicable, I request that the district release redacted versions of any withheld documents, removing only those specific portions deemed privileged or confidential. 

This approach aligns with the intent of CORA and the Colorado Court of Appeals ruling in Ritter v. Jones (2009), which affirmed that partial disclosure is appropriate when a document contains both public and exempt material.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter. I look forward to your response.
Sincerely,
Patrick Quigley

title: MBTA Transit Police Logs, Emails, and Maintenance Reports near Mass & Cass

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: MBTA Transit Police Logs, Emails, and Maintenance Reports near Mass & Cass
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I request the following records from the MBTA Transit Police Department for the time period  January 1, 2023 to present:

Regarding the following locations (and within a 0.25-mile radius):
Massachusetts Ave & Melnea Cass Blvd
Massachusetts Ave & Harrison Ave
Massachusetts Ave & Washington St
Massachusetts Ave & Albany St
1701 Washington St
Mass Ave orange line
Nubian Square bus terminal

1. All incident reports, arrest records, daily or monthly incident logs, and internal communications — including emails, text messages, or direct messages sent via platforms such as Microsoft Teams, Signal, Slack, or similar — for any event that occurred at or within 0.25 miles of the locations listed above.

 Please include incidents classified such as:

Drug or overdose-related activity
Medical or sick assist
Assaults
Trespass
Disturbance / disorderly conduct
Weapons-related
Hazardous conditions / property damage
Crime
Death
Disorderly conduct
Threats
Drug use or overdose
Public intoxication
Loitering or trespassing
Fare evasion
Mental health welfare checks
Officer-initiated stops or field interrogations

2. Any daily or monthly incident summary logs maintained by Transit Police that include these locations or surrounding areas.

3. Any internal memoranda, threat assessments, or safety alerts  issued by Transit Police related to these locations.

4. MBTA Maintenance Records
Please also provide any maintenance logs, service requests, or incident reports generated by MBTA Facilities, Customer Support, or contracted vendors for the following issues within 0.25 miles of the above listed stops from January 1, 2023 to present:

Needle disposal or sharps removal
Shelter or bench cleaning/repair
Biohazard cleanup (including bodily fluids, human waste, or hazardous materials)
Graffiti or vandalism
Reports of encampments or obstructions affecting bus operations or rider access
Please include the date, location, nature of the issue, and any available notes or photos submitted by field personnel. Records may be from mobile work order systems, internal ticketing systems, or third-party vendors.
Please include any responsive maintenance or service records that were initiated following MBTA Transit Police involvement or that correspond to any police-reported incidents described earlier in this request.

5. Complaints, Safety Audits, and Risk Assessments
Please provide all complaints, safety audits, risk assessments, or internal warnings received or issued by MBTA, Transit Police, MBTA Facilities, or contractors concerning public safety, crime, biohazards, or environmental dangers within 0.25 miles of the locations listed above. This includes complaints from riders, employees, operators, or third parties, whether submitted through formal channels or informally documented.

6. Legal, Risk Management, or Insurance Communications
Please provide any memoranda, emails, correspondence, or reports originating from MBTA Legal, Risk Management, or third-party insurers that reference public safety risks, legal liability, or potential claims involving the areas listed above. This includes discussions of assault, overdose, encampments, shelter degradation, or known environmental hazards.

7. Contractor Records and Work Logs
Please provide all work logs, service reports, and internal or contractor-submitted records relating to sanitation, shelter maintenance, needle/biohazard removal, or encampment response within the requested area. Include contracts, scopes of work, and any complaints by contractors about unsafe working conditions.

8. EMS / Medical Response Data
Please provide all EMS or overdose response records received, logged, or shared with MBTA Transit Police or Facilities,  staff dispatch records, overdose response logs, or incident summaries from January 1, 2023 to present for medical or overdose incidents within 0.25 miles of the listed locations. Include, if available, summary logs or patterns of repeated calls to the same location.

9. MBTA Employee Safety Reports and Grievances
Please provide all injury logs, incident reports, union grievances, or OSHA filings made by MBTA employees or contractors concerning assaults, injuries, or unsafe working conditions within 0.25 miles of the listed locations.

10. Withheld Safety Bulletins or Public Warnings
Please provide any internal communications regarding a decision not to issue a public safety bulletin, formal rider alert, or other public warning despite known or ongoing danger at or near the locations listed at the top of this request.

If no responsive records exist for a given item, please confirm that no such records exist.
Please identify the custodians and systems searched, and describe the methods used to locate responsive records.
If responsive records include databases, spreadsheets, or summary logs, please provide them in a machine-readable format (e.g., .csv or Excel).
Please include any available metadata showing dates of record creation, sender, and recipient, where applicable.
If responsive records exist in draft or revised form, please include those versions as well.
Please include any policies, notices, or instructions to staff regarding deletion, delay, or limitation of reporting incidents in the areas listed above.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brian McCarter

Crime 
Death 
Disorderly conduct 
Threats 
Drug use or overdose 
Public intoxication 
Loitering or trespassing 
Fare evasion 
Mental health welfare checks 
Officer-initiated stops or field interrogations 

2. Any daily or monthly incident summary logs maintained by Transit Police that include these locations or surrounding areas. 

3. Any internal memoranda, threat assessments, or safety alerts issued by Transit Police related to these locations. 

4. MBTA Maintenance Records 
Please also provide any maintenance logs, service requests, or incident reports generated by MBTA Facilities, Customer Support, or contracted vendors for the following issues within 0.25 miles of the above listed stops from January 1, 2023 to present: 

Needle disposal or sharps removal 
Shelter or bench cleaning/repair 
Biohazard cleanup (including bodily fluids, human waste, or hazardous materials) 
Graffiti or vandalism 
Reports of encampments or obstructions affecting bus operations or rider access 
Please include the date, location, nature of the issue, and any available notes or photos submitted by field personnel. Records may be from mobile work order systems, internal ticketing systems, or third-party vendors. 
Please include any responsive maintenance or service records that were initiated following MBTA Transit Police involvement or that correspond to any police-reported incidents described earlier in this request. 

5. Complaints, Safety Audits, and Risk Assessments 
Please provide all complaints, safety audits, risk assessments, or internal warnings received or issued by MBTA, Transit Police, MBTA Facilities, or contractors concerning public safety, crime, biohazards, or environmental dangers within 0.25 miles of the locations listed above. This includes complaints from riders, employees, operators, or third parties, whether submitted through formal channels or informally documented. 

6. Legal, Risk Management, or Insurance Communications 
Please provide any memoranda, emails, correspondence, or reports originating from MBTA Legal, Risk Management, or third-party insurers that reference public safety risks, legal liability, or potential claims involving the areas listed above. This includes discussions of assault, overdose, encampments, shelter degradation, or known environmental hazards. 

7. Contractor Records and Work Logs 
Please provide all work logs, service reports, and internal or contractor-submitted records relating to sanitation, shelter maintenance, needle/biohazard removal, or encampment response within the requested area. Include contracts, scopes of work, and any complaints by contractors about unsafe working conditions. 

8. EMS / Medical Response Data 
Please provide all EMS or overdose response records received, logged, or shared with MBTA Transit Police or Facilities, staff dispatch records, overdose response logs, or incident summaries from January 1, 2023 to present for medical or overdose incidents within 0.25 miles of the listed locations. Include, if available, summary logs or patterns of repeated calls to the same location. 

9. MBTA Employee Safety Reports and Grievances 
Please provide all injury logs, incident reports, union grievances, or OSHA filings made by MBTA employees or contractors concerning assaults, injuries, or unsafe working conditions within 0.25 miles of the listed locations. 

10. Withheld Safety Bulletins or Public Warnings 
Please provide any internal communications regarding a decision not to issue a public safety bulletin, formal rider alert, or other public warning despite known or ongoing danger at or near the locations listed at the top of this request. 

If no responsive records exist for a given item, please confirm that no such records exist. 
Please identify the custodians and systems searched, and describe the methods used to locate responsive records. 
If responsive records include databases, spreadsheets, or summary logs, please provide them in a machine-readable format (e.g., .csv or Excel). 
Please include any available metadata showing dates of record creation, sender, and recipient, where applicable. 
If responsive records exist in draft or revised form, please include those versions as well. 
Please include any policies, notices, or instructions to staff regarding deletion, delay, or limitation of reporting incidents in the areas listed above. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage. 

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Brian McCarter 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fmassachusetts-bay-transportation-authority-118%252Fmbta-transit-police-logs-emails-and-maintenance-reports-near-mass-cass-188255%252F%253Femail%253DMassDOT.RAO%252540state.ma.us&url_auth_token=AAAd0aBw8idrR1AhkkxjKvmyrBM%3A1uTXF8%3AeE385QB-6E4Be2yr2egD_96cHkiDA-MxDL8rXZuRfpc” 
Our Case No.: R000767-062225 

Dear Mr. McCarter, 

The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (“MBTA”) is in receipt of your request for public records regarding the above-referenced matter; this request was received by our Records Access Officer on June 22, 2025. 

You made a request for "................................" As part of a search for responsive records, I am advised that responsive records may exist [describe where records are and in what format]. 
Description of work to be done 

In order to fully comply with your request, and extensive manual search will need to be conducted to locate responsive records. Please be advised that records are not organized or tagged according to distance from specific coordinates. Therefore, numerous records must be searched for and pulled before an additional step can be made to determine if the subject matter concerns activity within the specific geographic radiuses. We estimate that several thousands of pages of material must be pulled, with personnel spending approximately three weeks, or 120 hours on the search and compilation aspect of the response. 

Once responsive records are located, and additional manual work of segregation and redaction will begin. As you may have seen or will soon see, the MBTA filed a fee petition seeking permission to charge for segregating and redacting records to the extent they contain information exempted under the Public Records Law. We currently estimate that 10-20,000 pages of material will need to be reviewed for segregation and redaction at 2 minutes per page. 

Once the records are reproduced in final form, they can be transmitted to you. 
Estimated time to complete described work 

Search and compilation time: 120.00 hours 

Segregation and redaction time: 500.00 hours 

Reproduction time: 5.00 hours 

Total estimated time: 625.00 hours 
Hourly rate and estimated fee 

Hourly rate: $25.00/hour. This hourly rate is equal to or less than the hourly rate attributed to the lowest paid employee who has the necessary skill required to search for, compile, segregate, redact or reproduce the records requested. 

No fee will be assessed for the first four hours of work. Therefore, the estimated cost of complying with your request is 621 hours of chargeable work at $25.00 per hour, or $15,525.00. This amount must be paid in advance and is just an estimate, which may change when the work is actually performed. If you would like the MBTA to perform the work described above, kindly send a check in the amount of $150.00 payable to the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, to my attention at 10 Park Plaza, Suite 3510, Boston, MA 02116. Additionally, we are happy to discuss an alternate scope so that records may be transmitted to you in a more efficient and affordable manner. 

Sincerely, 

Julie Ciollo 
Assistant General Counsel/ 
Records Access Officer

Dear Mr. McCarter, 
In response to appeal SPR 25/1943, I am providing you with additional information supporting the MBTA's fee estimate, which was sent to you on June 30, 2025. Specifically, the Supervisor of Records asked that the MBTA do the following: the Authority must clarify how it requires 120 hours to search for responsive records and 5 hours to reproduce responsive records. The Authority must also provide additional information regarding the tasks necessary to produce the responsive records. You have submitted 10 broad and at times vague requests. All of your requests ask for numerous categories of records, including the following: incident reports, arrest records, daily or monthly incident logs, and internal communications — including emails, text messages, or direct messages sent via platforms such as Microsoft Teams, Signal, Slack, or similar, daily or monthly incident summary logs maintained by Transit Police, internal memoranda, threat assessments, or safety alerts issued by Transit Police, maintenance logs, service requests, or incident reports generated by MBTA Facilities, Customer Support, or contracted vendors, memoranda, emails, correspondence, or reports originating from MBTA Legal, Risk Management, or third-party insurers that reference public safety risks, legal liability, or potential claims, work logs, service reports, and internal or contractor-submitted records relating to sanitation, shelter maintenance, needle/biohazard removal, or encampment response, EMS or overdose response records received, logged, or shared with MBTA Transit Police or Facilities, staff dispatch records, overdose response logs, or incident summaries from January 1, 2023 to present, all injury logs, incident reports, union grievances, or OSHA filings made by MBTA employees or contractors concerning assaults, injuries, or unsafe working conditions, internal communications regarding a decision not to issue a public safety bulletin, formal rider alert, or other public warning. Further, you have restricted the above categories to records related to a wide range of geographic areas. A full response will require numerous personnel across numerous MBTA departments to query databases or perform manual searches to compile potentially responsive areas. Because records are not categorized by proximity to a certain location, a manual review must take place to ensure that the subject matter matching your request comports with the chosen geographic areas. This work is compounded by the fact that you have chosen a time period of over two and a half years across every category of request. Given the numerous departments needed to engage on your requests, the dozens of categories of records, and the need for an extensive manual search to determine which records comport to the chosen geographic areas, we estimate each request may take at least 12 hours to complete the search and compilation portion of the MBTA's response. Please note that the MBTA does not permit tex messaging to be used for substantive business communications. If you wish you pursue any portion of your requests asking for text messages, please know that this is a manual search requiring an inspection of every MBTA-issued text-enabled device, of which there are hundreds if not thousands. The MBTA estimates at least 5 hours of reproduction time, which comports to 30 minutes per request. This work includes reproducing records in a redacted format once redactions have been applied, or uploading records that do not require any redaction. To the extent not already specified, the tasks needed to provide you with a full response include querying numerous databases and servers, reviewing records by hand to determine subject matter responsiveness, segregating and redacting responsive records, and reproducing records for you. Please be advised that the MBTA reserves the right to update this response or the fee estimate as the tasks involved in providing you with a response may change once the work is begun. Thank you for your attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, 
Julie Ciollo Assistant General Counsel/ Records Access Officer

communications.subject: RE: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request #R000767-062225
communications.communication:
Hello,

Pursuant to your public records request dated July 4, 2025 and received on July 7, 2025, requesting “[t]he complete administrative records for the following MBTA fee petition dockets:
SPR23/0192, SPR25/0354, SPR25/0771, SPR25/0789, SPR25/1599, SPR25/1743, SPR25/1835. For each of these prior dockets, please provide: 1. the original petition and supporting documents submitted by the MBTA, 2. any response or objection filed by the requester, 3. any communications between the Supervisor’s office and either party,” please find attached the records responsive to your public records request.

This Division redacted the records under Exemption (c) of the Public Records Law.

Exemption (c) applies to:

personnel and medical files or information and any other materials or data relating to a specifically named individual, the disclosure of which may constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy; provided, however, that this subclause shall not apply to records related to a law enforcement misconduct investigation. G. L. c. 4, § 7(26)(c).

Under Exemption (c), the Division is withholding the requestor’s personal email address for the following subject appeals referenced: SPR25/0354, SPR25/0789, SPR25/1599, SPR25/1743, and SPR25/1835. Disclosure of the redacted information would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.

You have the right to appeal this response to the Supervisor of Records pursuant to G. L. c. 66, § 10A(a), and to seek judicial review of an unfavorable decision by commencing a civil action in the superior court under G. L. c. 66, § 10A(c).

Very Respectfully,
Benjamin

Benjamin Chan (he/him/his)
Senior Legal Clerk
Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth
Public Records Division
One Ashburton Place, Room 1719
Boston, MA 02108
617-727-2832

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Request for Correctional Mental Health Staff Directory and Contact Information
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am requesting a list of currently employed mental health professionals within your state's Department of Corrections or its subsidiary agencies, as well as their contact information.

Specifically, I am requesting:

- Full names
- Job titles
- Assigned correctional facility
- Government-issued email addresses
- Government-issued phone numbers (direct desk numbers if available, otherwise department phone numbers with or without extensions)
- Department/division (e.g. Behavioral Health, Mental Health Services)

This request applies to the following roles: rehabilitative program coordinators, licensed psychologists, psychiatrists, clinical social workers, and other licensed mental health professionals serving incarcerated populations in state-operated facilities.

If available, I request this information be provided in a machine-readable format such as CSV or Excel.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Ma

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: 25-PRA-208 - MuckRock News (Andrew Ma)
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,



This is in response to your request for records from the California Correctional Health Care Services (CCHCS) under the California Public Records Act (CPRA), which was received in our office on July 7, 2025. Specifically, you requested the following:

Requesting a list of currently employed mental health professionals within your state's Department of Corrections or its subsidiary agencies, as well as their contact information.

Specifically, I am requesting:

*       Full names
*       Job titles
*       Assigned correctional facility
*       Government-issued email addresses
*       Government-issued phone numbers (direct desk numbers if available, otherwise department phone numbers with or without extensions)
*       Department/division (e.g. Behavioral Health, Mental Health Services)

This request applies to the following roles: rehabilitative program coordinators, licensed psychologists, psychiatrists, clinical social workers, and other licensed mental health professionals serving incarcerated populations in state-operated facilities.

If available, I request this information be provided in a machine-readable format such as CSV or Excel.

Please see the attached identified document:



*       CCHCS Mental Health Employee Listing 7.7.25



Please note that direct desk numbers were not disclosed within the above noted records as this information is protected from disclosure by the terms of the Public Records Act, including Government Code Sections 7927.700, 7927.705, and the Information Practices Act of 1977, specifically Civil Code Sections 1798.3(a) and 1798.24.  However, a phone number was provided in the "Department Phone Number" column for instances where the employee's work facility has a general phone number available to the public.



If you require any further assistance, you may contact us via e-mail at CCHCSHealthPRAS@CDCR.ca.gov<mailto:CCHCSHealthPRAS@CDCR.ca.gov>, or by regular mail at:



California Correctional Health Care Services

Attention: PRA Coordinator, Building C

P.O. Box 588500
Elk Grove, CA  95758



Sincerely,



G. Henderson
PRA Coordinator



GH/ip

CCHCSHealthPRAs@cdcr.ca.gov<mailto:CCHCSHealthPRAs@cdcr.ca.gov>

CCHCS CPRA Webpage:  PRA - CCHCS (ca.gov)<https://cchcs.ca.gov/pra/>







E-MAIL DISCLAIMER:  Please note that the information contained in this message may be privileged and confidential, protected from disclosure, and/or intended only for the use of the individual or entity named above. If the reader of this message is not the intended recipient, or an employee or agent responsible for delivering this message to the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any disclosure, distribution, copying or other dissemination of this communication is strictly prohibited. If you received this communication in error, please immediately reply to the sender, delete the message, and destroy all copies of it.

title: Property tax fraud ICO 16178 E. Franklin Rd, Ewing

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Property tax fraud ICO 16178 E. Franklin Rd, Ewing
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

All documents and investigative reports concerning report of possible tax fraud pertaining to property located at 16178 E. Franklin Rd Ewing, IL and individuals Melinda and Jestin Squires. The report is believed to have been made between October and December 2024 and closed with no charges made.

Records are of public interest to determine how reports of violation of tax laws are applied and enforced and whether there is equal application of the law.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Webster

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: FOIA Request: FY25 Organized Retail Crime Grant Program
communications.communication:
Dear MuckRock News:

The Village does not have any application in its possession or control.  Village personnel applied for the Organized Retail Crime Grant through an online portal administered by the Illinois Attorney General’s Office.  We are not sure how other law enforcement agencies completed an application.  They may have prepared a paper application or have print-outs from the Attorney General’s online portal.  But the Village of La Grange does not.  We cannot provide you records we do not have.

To the extent that you desire to see the application materials completed in the online portal, you may want to submit a request to the Illinois Attorney General’s Office.  We assume that the Attorney General’s Office has copies of all information submitted.

Thank you


[cid:image002.png@01DB9500.D12604F0]

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Opperman Investigation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

All investigative memos, interview transcripts, testimony transcripts, and legal filings from the investigation into the New York Department of Corrections and Community Supervision employee James Opperman over that employee’s sexual abuse of incarcerated people. For reference, the investigation took place after 2011, and the alleged abuse took place at Albion Correctional Facility.

The records I am requesting include records related to complaints, allegations, and charges, regardless of whether those complaints, allegations, and/or charges were substantiated. Per the February 20, 2025, Court of Appeals decision in Matter of New York Civil Liberties Union v. City of Rochester (2025 NY Slip Op 01010), the personal privacy exemption contained in Public Officers Law §87(2)(b) does not allow agencies to withhold complaints simply because they were not substantiated.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Gelardi

You may appeal denial of access to the redacted information by addressing a written appeal to FOIL Appeals Counsel Kenneth Michaels within 30 days.

Alexis Osborne + Stephen Del Giacco

I wanted to follow up on the following New York Freedom of Information Law request, copied below, and originally submitted on June 20, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #FOIL 057-2025.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: 057-2025 Response
communications.communication:
Re: FOIL 057-2025

Dear Chris Gelardi,

The attached document is provided to you in response to your request made below to the New York State Offices of the Inspector General pursuant to the Freedom of Information Law. The redactions to the document were made pursuant to Public Officers Law § 87 (2), which exempts from release records or portions thereof which, if released, would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy.

You may appeal denial of access to the redacted information by addressing a written appeal to FOIL Appeals Counsel Kenneth Michaels within 30 days.

Alexis Osborne + Stephen Del Giacco
Records Access Officers
NYS Offices of the Inspector General
Empire State Plaza | Agency Building 2, 16th Floor | Albany, New York 12223
Work: (518) 474-1010


[cid:image001.png@01DBF727.3D836C90]

If you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any dissemination or copying of this email is strictly prohibited. If you have received this email in error, please delete it and notify the sender by return email.

title: Ewing Grade School Board Nomination Petition

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Ewing Grade School Board Nomination Petition
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Nomination petition and receipt for statement of economic interest filing for Kyle Neal who ran and was elected to Ewing Grade School Board this year.

Any documents pertaining to the appointment of Jestin Squires to Ewing Grade School Board vacancy following the 2025 election.

Voter registration data for 14425 Rescue Church Rd, Whittington, IL showing residents registered to vote at the address.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Webster

communications.subject: RE: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Ewing Grade School Board Nomination Petition
communications.communication:

In a previous email dated 7/11/2025 an Economic Interest Statement was sent for Jestin Squires.  I have sent your email to our Election Office, for Paris Dunk to contact you regarding Kyle Neal.  Should you need to reach him, you can contact him by email paris.dunk@franklincountyil.gov <mailto:paris.dunk@franklincountyil.gov>   or call 618-435-9800 ext. 405.

communications.subject: FOIA
communications.communication:
To whom it may concern,

Hello my name is Paris Dunk, with the Franklin County Election office, and I was forwarded this FOIA request due to some of the request falling into documents and information that we would have on file.

  1.  I have attached the requested Nomination Petition and receipt of Statement of economic interest for Kyle Neal.


  1.  As far as the records of appointment of Jestin Squires, you would need to contact the Ewing Grade school district directly for that information because that is not a record we regularly maintain.



  1.  The voter registration information we have for 14425 Rescue Church Road shows that Jestin Squires is the only registered voter at that address.

title: Medical Policies for Blood Borne Pathogens (Pima County Sheriff)

communications.subject: Arizona Public Records Law Request: Medical Policies for Blood Borne Pathogens (Pima County Sheriff)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Arizona Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

1- Any directives, regulations, manuals, memos, or other training materials given to all staff—both medical and correctional—related to handling or managing prisoners with blood borne pathogens including but not limited Hepatitis C or HIV/AIDS.  This could be in the form of training materials on how to quarantine individuals with blood borne pathogens, or training materials for correctional staff on what to do when coming into contact with someone who has a blood borne pathogen. 

2- Any emergency preparedness manuals, directives, or training materials for when a viral outbreak occurs (this could also be referred to as a “pandemic procedure".)

3- Any medical directives, memos, regulations, or staff training around prescribing the medical protocol of PrEP (pre-exposure prophylaxis).

4- Any directives, regulations, manuals, memos, or other training materials given to staff on housing criteria for specific populations (e.g. women, youth, those with illnesses, etc.)

5- Employee handbook given to correctional staff upon hiring, as well as any employee handbook given separately to medical staff

I am also requesting the following data and forms:

1- Aggregate data by month on the number of prisoners with HIV and Hep C for the last two years. If this data exists only in a format that requires creation of a new record, please provide the data in its original format and remove identifying information.

2- A copy of the standard medical intake form used for prisoners or people held inside the facility.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Joseph Darius Jaafari

The Pima County Sheriff's Department has completed your request for JAIL INFORMATION regarding MEDICAL POLICIES FOR BLOOD BORNE PATHOGENS and the cost for these records is $7.50.

Please note, these documents will only be retained for a period of 30 calendar days from today's date after which point you will be required to resubmit a request for these documents.

You have been sent an invoice from Clover to make your payment. They accept Visa and MasterCard. Once payment is received, your documents will be sent to you as indicated from your original request. We do not fax records.

*Should your email address come back as invalid/undeliverable we will revert to mailing your item(s) to the mailing address provided on your request*

Please keep in mind that payments made outside of business hours will not be accepted until the next business day.

If you do not want to make on online payment you can;

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: talk2.seattle.gov emails
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The following metadata for all emails the Kent Police Department has received from "@talk2.seattle.gov" between June 1, 2025 and the date this request was processed:
- Sender
- Recipient (To, CC, BCC)
- Date and time sent
- Subject

As this is a request for metadata only, please do not include the email body in the returned records. I request that this data be provided in Excel or CSV format if possible.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

public records. The City estimates  it will provide a further response
within 5 business days with a determination regarding disclosure, denial, or if

extend this time frame if necessary.

thank you for using the Public Records Center.

On 7/13/2025, you submitted a public records request to the City of Kent wherein you sought Police Department Records for: The following metadata for all emails the Kent Police Department has received from 
"@talk2.seattle.gov" between June 1, 2025 and the date this request was processed: 
- Sender

- Date and time sent 
- Subject 
As this is a request for metadata only, please do not include the email body in the 
returned records. I request that this data be provided in Excel or CSV format if possible The City advised you it anticipated responding to your request within 5 business days. The City now needs  to extend this estimate; and currently estimates it will be able to provide responsive records, either on an installment basis or in total by 08/15/2025 . 
This additional time is necessary due to current staffing levels, current volume of public record requests received; locating and assembling the requested records; if necessary notifying any third parties who may be affected by the request; and to determine whether any of the information contained within the requested records is exempt from disclosure, in whole or in part. If you have any questions, please contact the City Clerk’s Office at 253-856-5725. Thank you. Sincerely, Tiffany Alcorn Tiffany Alcorn CPRO - Lead Public Disclosure Administrator City of Kent Administration 
Arthur “Pat” Fitzpatrick, Chief Administrative Officer

Dear Rose Terse:

 
On 7/13/2025, you submitted a public records request to the City of Kent wherein you sought Police Department Records Request for:

communications.subject: Minnesota Government Data Practices Act Request: Minnesota SEA response
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Minnesota Government Data Practices Act, I hereby request the following records:

All documentation submitted to the U.S. Department of Education's Student Privacy Policy Office in response to the office's March 28, 2025, request for records such as "'reports, information on policies and procedures, annual notifications, training materials or other information necessary' to provide assurance that the SEA and their respective LEAs are complying with the provisions of FERPA and PPRA".

I have attached a copy of the SPPO's request letter for reference. The relevant section is found on the last page, under "Assurance of Compliance". The SPPO requested the documentation be submitted no later than April 30, 2025. If the Minnesota Department of Education sent communications to the SPPO requesting an extension or declining to submit the documentation, I request a copy of said communications.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The current roster of sworn officers in the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department.
These documents should be sufficient to show:
- Names of each sworn police officer. 
- Current badge number
- Current rank
- Gender
- Race
- Date of employment
- Photo, such as a headshot or other identifying photo.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Hartley

Your request was received in this office on 6/24/2025 and given the reference number P050968-062425 for tracking purposes. 
You requested the following records: "To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The current roster of sworn officers in the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department.
These documents should be sufficient to show:
- Names of each sworn police officer.
- Current badge number
- Current rank
- Gender
- Race
- Date of employment
- Photo, such as a headshot or other identifying photo.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kristina Hartley

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Findianapolis-police-department-660%252Fcurrent-impd-roster-188356%252F%253Femail%253DIMPDRecordsRequest%252540indy.gov&url_auth_token=AAARlcjhVTOdu_O3ZOzcydkluP4%3A1uUEkI%3ATUkmmCGHRt7-kz32rRLc8pX8OexTKXwF5_iqQFdlvF8" 
Your request will be forwarded to the relevant city or county agency for review and a determination of whether there are public records responsive to your request and, if so, whether those public records are disclosable to you. The city or county agency will contact you concerning your request and inform you whether there are public records responsive to your request, if all or part of those public records are not disclosable to you, and the statutory basis for any denial. Information pertaining to any copying fees that may be related to obtaining copies will be provided. 
Please Note:  With respect to public records requests that include e-mail communications, we want to make you aware that these requests generally take longer than requests for other types of information.  First, the City/County receives a large number of requests for email communications, not just public records requests but also related to legal proceedings.  We rely upon our information technology agency to perform these searches and that agency runs these searches (based  upon reasonably particular search terms as set forth by the State Public Access Counselor) in the order in which the requests are received.  Once the email search is completed, there must also be a review of the content of the email communications to ensure that they are not only responsive to your request but also disclosable.  Finally, disclosable email communications will be produced after this review and if we do not disclose all or part of these email communications, we will provide the statutory bases for such denials as required under the APRA. 
The APRA requires public agencies to produce responsive and disclosable public records, should they exist, within a reasonable time based upon the circumstances.   Please allow the agency time to review and process your request. 
While there is no fixed due date for a response, if more than 30 days have passed since your last communication with the agency, feel free to contact the Public Access Counselor to check the status. 
You may reach the Public Access Counselor at 317.327.4055 or PAC@indy.gov. 
Thank you, 
City of Indianapolis and Marion County

communications.subject: City of Seattle Public Records Request Center - Invoice Ready :: C225965-051825
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Records in response to your public disclosure request C225965-051825 received on May 18, 2025 are now available. The cost for the records is as follows: 
 
Invoice Number: INV25-C225965-1 
Total: $1.25 
 
To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 Please note that you will need to disable any pop-up blockers to make a payment using the system. 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Find this request: C225965-051825. 
  * Select the 'View Invoices' button. 
 
  * Opens a pop-up window showing your invoice: INV25-C225965-1. 
  * Click on the invoice and then the 'Pay Now' button. 
  * Continue processing your payment. 
  * Select 'Done'. 
  * Once the payment process is done, you are returned to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * After your payment is successful you will receive an email from our payments center. 
Once your payment has been approved, we will send you an email with instructions on how to download your records. Note that City staff must manually upload records. Records will be available one to two business days after payment. 
 
Please let your public disclosure officer (PDO) know if you are unable to pay online; your PDO will work with you on alternative ways to make your payment. 
 
You have 30 days from today's date to pay for your records. If the City does not receive your payment within this time period, your request will be considered abandoned, and you will need to submit a new request. 
 Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your E-mail contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center E-mails to your Inbox. (mailto:seattle@mycusthelp.net) 
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

title: Kentucky State Police Open Records Request - Quattrone Center

communications.subject: Kentucky Open Records Act Request: Kentucky State Police Open Records Request - Quattrone Center
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Kentucky Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Kentucky State Police (KSP),

Dear KSP,

Pursuant to the Kentucky Revised Statutes Open Records KRS 61.870 – 61.884, I am requesting access to all records related to the purchase of field drug testing supplies and technologies (used to identify unknown substances that are potentially contraband) by your agency from January 1, 2016 to the present. 

1.	Specifically, I am requesting contracts your agency or department has with providers of drug testing kit or device providers (such as colorimetric or presumptive field tests or testing insurance), or any other records indicating the quantity, cost, vendor, and model of each item or system purchased. This request includes materials related to but not limited to the following:
o	Colorimetric or presumptive field test kits, such as: 
	NIK Public Safety kits 
	Sirchie NARK II kits
	Field Forensics DABIT kits
	Mistral drug identification/detection kits
	M.M.C. International B.V. presumptive drug tests
	TN Scientific Mandelin Reagent drug testing kits
	Macherey-Nagel MEDI-TEST
	Any other colorimetric or presumptive kits
o	Instrument-based technologies, including: 
	Raman spectroscopy devices
	Infrared (IR) spectroscopy devices
	Ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) devices
	Mass spectrometry (MS) devices
	Any other field-portable drug identification technologies
1.	Total annual budget allocated to the purchase or acquisition of such drug testing kits or devices.
2.	Spending information (such as invoices, purchase orders, or receipts) for any presumptive drug testing kits or devices.
3.	This request does not include urine, blood, or other tests designed to identify drug compounds in the human body. This request is made as part of an academic research project examining the use and cost of field drug testing technologies by law enforcement and correctional agencies nationwide. If possible, I request that the records be provided in electronic format (PDF, Excel, or CSV).

If any part of this request is denied, please provide a written explanation for the denial, including the specific exemption(s) relied upon. If the requested records are available in part, I request access to all segregable portions. Should there be any material cost (defined as more than $100) associated with providing the requested information, please provide me with an estimate before proceeding with any work.

Please contact me at QuattroneResearch@law.upenn.edu or 215-746-1251 if you have any questions or require clarification. Thank you for your time and assistance.

Sincerely,

 
Ross Miller
Assistant Director
Quattrone Center for the Fair Administration of Justice

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ross Miller

communications.subject: Your Kentucky State Police public records request #25-6288 has been submitted.
communications.communication:
Kentucky State Police ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-6288 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for submitting your request to the Kentucky State Police, Public Records Branch. The estimated response time is 5 business days. Please be advised that a public agency is not statutorily required to answer questions or provide information as opposed to public records. See 21-ORD-034. Please be advised, any records you may receive will be inaccessible after thirty days from our response date. As the requester, you can always see the status of your request by signing into the Kentucky State Police portal. If you haven't already signed in, you may need to activate or setup your account to get started. Once your account is activated, you can communicate directly with the Kentucky State Police through NextRequest. ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact Kentucky State Police.

Change your email settings | Visit our help center
